awd_titl_txt: SL- CN: The role of gesture in mathematics learning: from research to practice
awd_abstract_narration:
This Science of Learning Collaborative Network brings together researchers and practitioners at the University of Chicago and Northeastern Illinois University to investigate the impact of nonverbal cues on math learning, and to develop online math lessons accessible to diverse learners based on this research-based evidence.  Online education offers the promise that it can serve as an "equity lever" by making education accessible to all children, including low-income and disadvantaged children. But it is not clear that online teaching is as effective as face-to-face teaching, in part because it eliminates many of the nonverbal cues, including gesture, that have been found to promote learning. This network will conduct basic research exploring the impact that nonverbal cues have on math learning in both deaf and hearing children, and then use this research to develop online instruction that makes effective use of nonverbal cues for diverse learners. Deaf scientists are underrepresented in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) fields, suggesting a pipeline problem for deaf students and highlighting a need to improve math teaching for these students. The studies will also consider the socioeconomic levels of the homes from which the students come, and thus have relevance not only to learners who come to school from privileged backgrounds, but also to learners who have access to fewer resources. 

This Science of Learning Collaborative Network consists of collaborators representing ten universities from psychology, linguistics, computer science, and neuroscience with three types of expertise: scientists who study gesture and its role in learning math and science; scientists who study language development from a linguistic perspective; and scientists who are at the intersection of basic and applied research, and are involved in educational practice or policy and technology development. The purpose of the network is three-fold: (1) To advance knowledge of the impact that nonverbal cues have on mathematics instruction. (2) To explore whether nonverbal cues have different effects on different learners, in particular hearing vs. deaf learners from low vs. high SES homes. (3) To translate research into practice by developing an online teaching tool that is accessible to learners with diverse backgrounds. The proposed studies involve presenting lessons on mathematical equivalence and fraction magnitudes in different input mediums to different groups of learners. The studies include quantitative measures of behavioral and neurological learning outcomes. The research findings will be used to inform the development of online math lessons that can be adapted to the needs of different types of learners. 

The award is from the Science of Learning-Collaborative Networks (SL-CN) Program, with funding from the SBE Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences (BCS), the SBE Office of Multidisciplinary Activities (SMA), the EHR Core Research (ECR) Program, and the CISE Division of Computer and Network Systems (CNS).

por.por_cntn:
The funded research focused on the role that gesture can potentially play for hearing and deaf children’smath learning in the online/remote instructional context. The Covid-19 pandemic has amplified the needto make computer online instruction a viable and alternative method of dispensing education. Yetschools—especially those in low-income areas—have struggled to adapt to remote and online instruction,compromising educational goals and deeply affecting marginalized and low-income children’s early mathlearning, impacting their later acquisition of complex math understanding, and preventing manyindividuals from entering STEM fields. The United States ranks 39 out of 70 industrialized countries inmath competence. This challenge points to the weakness of our instructional capacity and the lack ofsystematic examination of what works in education, who education works for, and how to improveinstruction, particularly math instruction. Translating educational practices to online venues becomes animportant task of researchers and educators as online instruction becomes more ubiquitous. We needmore science about how learning comes about in an online context to determine what input should beprovided online and what form it should take. Using technology that simulates an online learningexperience, this research explored how to improve children’s understanding of two fundamental but basicmath concepts; the equal sign and fraction magnitude, each of which determines later learning of morecomplex math. The equal sign means that both sides of an equation has to be the same amount. Despiteits importance for later math understanding, 80% of children in the U.S. fail to understand what the equalsign means. Fraction understanding has also proven to be a struggle for students and prevents theirability to master complex concepts in math and science. We examined the use of gesture––manualmovement that presents mathematical ideas through accessible imagery––as a tool to improve mathteaching. Gesture is commonly and spontaneously used by teachers and students in classroominstruction yet has not been fully explored experimentally as a tool for learning. The research asked 3questions: (1) How does instruction that includes gesture enhance comprehension of math for children ina context that simulates online learning? (2) Does gesture enhance learning across deaf and hearingpopulations? (3) Is gesture’s impact on learning altered through its timing with speech? The results showthat gesture significantly enhances learning of the equal sign in children ages 8 through 11, particularlywhen gesture is provided simultaneously with speech (as opposed to before or after a spoken statement).Gesture enhances learning in both deaf and hearing populations. The exploration of fraction learningrevealed that children use gesture when explaining fraction knowledge, and that these gestures indicatemore fundamental understanding and potential for growth in that understanding than their speech, whichoften expresses superficial and inadequate fraction ideas. This project provides preliminary informationabout gesture’s role in online learning, paving the way for gesture to increase equity of math learningacross diverse populations and promote access to foundational STEM concepts and careers. Gestureprovided with instruction has the potential to level the playing field for students known to be under-resourced in education such as the deaf population.
